text: A working-class funeral in progress. THIRTY PEOPLE and an inexpensive bier SEEN from the back of the hall.

A MAN's back FILLS the SCREEN. He is dressed in a black s his hands are clasped behind him. ANOTHER MAN stands next him. The Second Man reaches behind the First Man's back a puts a discreetly folded ten-dollar bill into his hands.
These Two Men from the front. Both somber, in their early fifties. They begin to walk down the aisle of the funeral parlor.
The WIDOW. A woman in her late fifties sitting by the bie receiving condolences. The Two Men approach her. The Firs Man (the recipient of the money) speaks:
Mrs. Dee, this is Frank Galvin -- a  very good friend of ours, and a very  fine attorney.
It's a shame about your husband,  Mrs. Dee.
The Widow nods.
I knew him vaguely through the Lodge.  He was a wonderful man. (shakes head in  sympathy) It was a crime what happened to him.  A crime. If there's anything that I  could do to help...
GALVIN removes a business card from his jacket pocket and hands it to her as if he were giving her money. (i.e., "T it. Really. I want you to have it..." She takes the card. Beat.
(thoughtfully realizes  he is usurping her  time) Well...
He shakes her hand and moves on.
Galvin sitting in the deserted coffee shop in his raincoa Reading a section of the paper. He picks up his teacup,  drinks. Lowers it to the table.

Galvin twists tea bag around a spoon to extract last drop of tea. His hand moves to his felt pen lying on the table He moves his hand to the paper, open at the obituary sect We SEE several names crossed out. He circles one funeral  listing.
Galvin sitting, raises cup of tea to his lips. Looks arou deserted coffee shop. Sighs.
Galvin outside a second funeral home. WORKING-CLASS PEOPL entering, Galvin enters the home.

Galvin, coming down the aisle toward the front, shrugging himself out of his overcoat, he approaches the BEREAVED W sitting by the front of the home, he extracts his card fr his pocket, starts to speak. He is stopped by the WIDOW'S SON, a hefty man in his mid-forties, who interjects himse between Galvin and the widow.
(of the card) What is that...?
What the hell is that...
...I was a friend of your fa...
You never knew my father. (hits card out of  Galvin's hand) You get out of here, who the hell do  you think you are...
The FUNERAL MANAGER hurries down the aisle, and starts  extricating Galvin from the commotion.
(to Funeral Manager) I'm talking to this man...
Excuse me, Mrs. Cleary...
He is manhandling Galvin toward the back of the funeral  parlor. The Son calls after him:
Who the hell do you think you are?
The Funeral Manager and Galvin standing in the cold.
I don't want you coming back here.  Ever. Do you understand?
I was just talking to...
Those are bereaved people in there.
The Funeral Manager gives Galvin a small shove, and goes  back to his post at the door, greeting the entering mourn "Good evening..."
Galvin, the ground cut out from under him. Standing watch the mourners enter.

Galvin walking down a residential street. He has been wal a while in the cold, snowy night. He stops for a stopligh at a corner, waits for the light although there is no tra Lights a cigarette. The light changes. He looks both ways and irresolutely starts across the street. He stops. He c his watch. He sighs, and starts back in the opposite  direction.
Galvin holding forth at the bar of a seedy drinking-man's establishment, THREE DRINKERS, acquaintances, standing ar him, appreciative.
Pat says, 'Mike... there's a new  bar, you go in, for a half a buck  you get a beer, a free lunch, and  then take you in the back room and  they get you laid.'
The bartender, JIMMY, comes up to Galvin.
Another, Frank...?

(gestures to include  group) ...everybody. Mike says, 'Pat, you  mean to tell me for a buck you get a  free lunch and a beer, and then you  go in the back and get laid?' 'That's  correct.' Mike says, 'Pat. Have you  been in this bar ?' Pat says, 'No,  but my sister has...' (gestures to Jimmy) Everyone. Buy yourself one too.

The seedy, disorganized small office, Galvin in shirt-sle opening a file cabinet. He takes out an armload of files, carries them to a wastebasket and throws them in. He sits his desk, as if exhausted by his effort, pours from a whi bottle into a large water glass, downs the glass. He has been drinking for some time. He starts stumbling b to the file cabinet. On the way his eye is caught by his  degrees hanging on the wall. He stumbles to them, picks t up and walks over to the wastebasket and throws them in. goes back to the file cabinet, the phone starts ringing.  Galvin lets it ring, continues emptying the files into th wastebasket, tearing some of them up as he does so. He repeats softly to himself, as a litany, "It doesn't ma a bit of difference, it doesn't make a bit of difference. He starts back to the desk for the bottle, knocks the sti ringing phone off the desk. He pours himself a drink. As he downs it we hear -- softly -- from the phone on the floor: a MAN'S VOICE. "Frank. Frank. Frank. Goddamnit. Ar you there...? Frank..." Galvin pays no attention. Drinks his drink and gazes at the wall -- now empty of  degrees. ANGLE - P.O.V. The empty wall. Galvin's P.O.V. The telephone heard Voice Over insisting, "Frank..."

MICKEY MORRISSEY, a man in his late sixties, dressed in s and overcoat, looking worried, unlocks the door to the da anteroom. Looks around. Sees something in the next room. ANGLE - P.O.V. Galvin asleep on his couch, clothed as before. Covered in his overcoat, the bottle and glass next to the couch on t floor, the sound of the phone off the hook.
Mickey walks into the office. Stands looking at Galvin.
(harshly) Get up. (beat, more harshly) Get up.
Galvin wakes up. Looks around. Swings his legs over the c Drinks from the glass. Vacantly:
Hi, Mickey...
What the hell do you think you're  doing...? (surveys the wrecked  office) What's going on here...?
Uh...
Fuck you. I got a call today from  Sally Doneghy...
...now who is that...?
...You're 'sposed to be in court in  ten days and she's telling me you  haven't even met with them...
Sally Doneghy, now who is that?
One lousy letter eighteen months  ago... I try to throw a fuckin' case  your way...
...hey, I don't need your charity...

...I get these people to trust you --  they're coming here tomorrow by the  way -- I get this expert doctor to  talk to you. I'm doing all your  fuckin' legwork -- and it's eighteen  months. You're 'sposed to be in court.  I bet you haven't even seen the file.
Galvin pours himself a drink.
Hey, what are you, my nanny?
Mickey walks to him, knocks the drink out of his hand and slaps him several times in the face.

Listen to me. Listen to me... listen  to me, Frank, 'cause I'm done fuckin'  with you. I can't do it any more.  Look around you: You think that you're  going to change? What's going to  change it? You think it's going to  be different next month? It's going  to be the same. And I have to stop.  This is it. I got you a good case,  it's a moneymaker. You do it right  and it will take care of you. But  I'm through. I'm sorry, Frank, this  is the end. (beat) Life is too short, and I'm too old. (beat)
Mickey walks out of the office. Slams the door. Beat. Galvin looks around the office. Goes to his sofa. Sits,  reaches to side table.
The side table, a pack of Luckies. Galvin taking one, his hand shaking a little. Also on side table a pile of chang containing a small rosary and a wedding ring.

The carriage of a typewriter. A sheet of paper. Its lette reads "Frank P. Galvin. Attorney at Law, 124 State Street Boston, Mass. 02981. Cable FRAGAL." Someone is typing, "S I had to go out. Back at 10. Judge Geary called. Are you  available for lunch Wednesday University Club?" A hand ta a paper from carriage and puts it on desk. Takes a pen an signs, "Claire."

Galvin in the anteroom, dressed in his suit, unshaved, ha just signed the paper. He takes a piece of Scotch tape fr the dispenser on the desk, picks up a file folder from th coffee table. It is torn in several places and rudely Sco taped.
The file headed Deborah Ann Kaye v. St. Catherine Laboure Hospital et. al.
Galvin surveys the anteroom, opens door to corridor, Scot tapes the note he has just typewritten to the outside of door.

Dark paneling, clean, simple. A drinkers' bar. OLD BARTEN and THREE CUSTOMERS spaced widely, Galvin in his overcoat downing a shot, the file open before him. He is reading. He checks his watch, scoops the file together under his a throws a dollar on the bar, and heads for the door.

Galvin walking tentatively down the corridor of a very ru nursing home. He receives suspicious looks from the  Attendants. He is checking numbers on the doors against a notation in the file. He finds the correct door and enter

The door to the ward from the inside. Galvin opening the  door to the dark ward, backlit, tentative, a little unste from his drinking. He puts his back against the door, put down file and briefcase, extracts a small cheap Polaroid  camera from the briefcase, readies it to shoot, picks up paraphernalia, and starts off down the ward. As he walks  down the ward he checks the file hung at the foot of each bed. Galvin stops at the foot of one bed and reads the ch ANGLE - P.O.V. The chart held by Galvin. DEBORAH ANN KAYE, various medic notations. He lowers the chart and we SEE in the bed beyo it a shriveled, tiny form stuck with needles and tubes.

Galvin replaces the chart, puts his file, briefcase, etc. the foot of the bed, takes a flash photo of the figure in the bed. Takes another one. Puts down camera, sits on the end of the bed gazing at the unseen form. He lights a  cigarette, and sits looking at her.
SALLY DONEGHY. A mousy woman in her forties is standing b door on which is written, "Frank P. Galvin. Attorney at L
I'm... Mrs. Doneghy? I'm Frank  Galvin... why didn't you go in?
It's locked.
(astonished) It's locked?
Sally Doneghy points to the note on the door. Galvin take it from the door. Reads. "Back at 10, Judge Geary. Lunch.
I'm terribly sorry... I hope we didn't  put you out. Won't you come in...? (motions Sally into  inner office, gestures  with note) I'd offer you some coffee, but it  looks like my girl just went out.
Galvin is perched at his secretary's desk. Sally Doneghy  across from him by the coffee table listening intently.
It's not a good case. It's a very  good case.
A healthy young woman goes into the  hospital to deliver her third child,  she's given the wrong anesthetic...
...we, we love her, Dick and me...
...I'm sure you do...
But what can we do? She don't know  who's visiting her...
...I know. I went...
...You saw her?
Yes. Yes, I have.

You know how beautiful she was? (beat) Her husband left her, and he took  her kids... They, they, they'd let  you die in there. They don't care.  Nobody cares. The Patriot Home, the  Chronic Care... in Arlington...?  They'd take her in. Perpetual care.  They'd take her. Fifty thousand  dollars they want. An endowment.
...fifty thousand dollars?
I don't want to leave her. Dick...  the, the... and Father Laughlin, he  said that it was God's will...
...I understand...
My doctor told me that I got to move  out West... that's when we filed in  court. We didn't want to sue...
...I understand...
...But Dick, he's looking for two  years in Tucson... and they called  him up and said to come out. He's a  good man. He's only trying to do  what's right.
The door to the corridor opens and DICK DONEGHY, a workin in his forties, comes into the room. Sally and Galvin sta
This is my husband.
Donegy and Galvin shake hands uncomfortably. He motions t two to sit.
Please sit down. I told your wife.  I'm sorry that we have to meet out  here. I've got a case coming in two  days in the Superior Court and my  office is a mess of papers.
...that's all right.
I was telling your wife, we have a  very good case here.
He saw her at the Northern Care...
...and I have inquiries out to  doctors, experts in the field...  there is, of course, a problem getting  a doctor to testify that another  doctor's negligent...
...the Archdiocese called up, they  said who was our attorney, 'cause  the case is coming to trial...
I doubt we'll have to go to trial...
...we told them we didn't want it to  come out this way.
I completely understand...
We just...
We just can't do it anymore. (beat) This is our chance to get away.
I'm going to see you get that chance.
What is this going to cost?
It's completely done on a contingency  basis. That means whatever the  settlement is I retain one-third...  that is, of course, the usual  arrangement...
Yellowed newspaper clipping, a very lovely, patrician wom in her twenties smiling at a well-turned-out Galvin aroun thirty. Headline: "Patricia Harrington to Wed."
His name is Frank Galvin. B.U. Law,  class of 'fifty-two. Second in his  class. Editor of the Law Review.  Worked with Mickey Morrissey twelve  years. Criminal Law and Personal  Injury...'
A hand turns a page and reveals a second clipping: "Bosto Lawyer Held in Jury Tampering Case," with a picture of a  very confused Galvin at around forty-five being led to ja
'Married Patricia Harrington, nineteen  sixty...'

The small, sumptuously appointed Italianate office. French windows, a fire in the grate, a view of Boston Com JOSEPH ALITO, a slender, elegant man in his forties dress in a very expensive suit, reading from his notes, news  clippings, etc., which are held in a leather folder.
'Joined Stearns, Harrington, Pierce  nineteen sixty as a full partner.  Resigned the firm nineteen sixt-ynine  over the Lillibridge case...' Do  you...?
Alito, strolling as he reads, moves toward the windows wi his file TO REVEAL BISHOP BROPHY, a self-contained man in his early sixties, sitting on a leather couch, listening.
He was accused of jury tampering.

Accused. Not indicted. He resigned  the firm. Divorced nineteen seventy.  Galvin worked with Michael Morrissey  until Morrissey retired in 'seventy- eight. Since then he's been on his  own. Four cases before the Circuit  Court. He lost them all. He drinks.
Four cases in three years...
The man's an ambulance chaser...
...tell me about this case.
This is a nuisance suit. He's looking  for small change. He's asking for  six hundred thousand and betting we  don't want to go to court.
No -- we don't want this case in  court.
Neither does he. That's where he  loses. This man's scared to death to  go to court. We only have to call  his bluff.
I want to settle this thing and be  done with it. I don't want the  Archdiocese exposed.
No. Absolutely, and we're going to  see that it is not.
So what I want to do is stop it here.  I'm going to make him an offer. I  want to do it myself. I want it to  come from me.
All right. But let's keep the price  down. I've called Ed Concannon. He  recommends that we continue to respond  as if we're going to trial.
The Bishop nods, meaning, "You are dismissed." As an  afterthought:
If we were to go to trial, would we  win the case?
Well, of course, it's always  dangerous...
I know that answer. If we went to  trial would we win?
(in an "of course"  tone) Yes.
Alito, preparing to leave, reaches to the Bishop's desk,  where he has laid his leather folder.
The clipping in the folder, confused Galvin being led int jail, "Boston Lawyer Held in Jury Tampering Case." Alito' hand snaps the folder shut.
A man's arms full of textbooks. Prominently displayed: "Methodology and Practice in Anesthesiology." The man sto fumbles for a key in his pocket.
Galvin, in his overcoat, arms full of books, reading from textbook and trying to unlock his office door.
Galvin entering. CLAIRE PAVONE, a woman in her fifties, a the secretary's desk, hanging up the phone.
(to phone) Thank you very much.
Galvin looks up at her in surprise.
What are you doing here?
Mickey told me to come back to work.
Galvin nods, proceeds into his office, reading from the  textbook. Claire follows him into the office.
...here's your mail, call Mrs.  Doneghy...
...yes. Get her on the phone...
...that was a Dr. David Gruber's  office...
(putting down books) Gruber...

Mickey told him to call. (reading from notes) 'He's some very hotshot surgeon at  Mass. Commonwealth. He wants to meet  with you at seven tonight re testimony  in the case of Deborah Ann Kaye. You  meet him at the hospital.'
She hands him typed memo slip.
(surprised) ...he wants to testify...?
It looks that way.
You know what that would mean?
To get somebody from a Boston hospital  to say he'll testify?
...a Mrs. Doneghy called... I told  you that.
Phone rings. Claire moves to it.
(delighted) This is going to drive the ante up.
(into phone) Frank Galvin's... who's calling  please? Bishop Brophy's office...
She gestures to Galvin, "Do you want to talk to them?" Ga gestures back, "No. I'm not in..."
I'm sorry, he's not in... may I take  a mess... tomorrow when, two  o'clock... I'll check my book...
She looks to Galvin, who nods, "yes."
Yes. Mr. Galvin's clear at that  time... the Bishop's office, tomorrow,  the fifth at two p.m. Thank you...
She hangs up.
That's the call that I'm waiting  for.
What does it mean?
They want to settle. (beat) It means a lot of money.
Does that mean I'm back for awhile?
Man's wrist. WWII GI watch reads: 6:56.
Galvin in overcoat standing outside door marked "Doctors  Only" in bustling hospital corridor. He glances at memo s in his hand. He opens door. CAMERA FOLLOWS him onto:

Carpeted, small, comfortable, lined in lockers. A DOCTOR, the phone in greens, smoking a cigarette, talking on the  phone softly, a couple of DOCTORS sitting, drinking coffe chatting. Galvin, a trifle nervous, to Doctor ON PHONE:
Dr. Gruber...?
The Doctor on the phone gestures behind him to a thirty-i MAN in blue jeans smoking a cigar, changing at his locker Galvin walks over to him.
Dr. Gruber...
(turning) Yes? Galvin, right?
He checks his watch, continues changing into suede jacket checks next appointment on a leather appointment book, lo the locker, pockets key.
I appreciate -- a man as busy as --
That's perfectly all right. I'm kind  of rushed. Do you mind if we walk  while we talk?
Gruber, Galvin following, talk while exiting locker room.
I read the hospital report on your  client.
...Deborah Ann Kaye...
...Deborah Ann Kaye...
They walk hurriedly through a hospital corridor, to an EX door and down concrete stairs.
They called, they're going to settle,  what I want to do is build up as  much...
Right. Who called?
The Archdiocese called, they want to  settle... her estate...
...and you're going to do that?
(surprised, of course) Yes.
You're going to settle out of court?
Gruber stops at the bottom of the stairs, beside an exit the outside.
Yes.
Why?
A beat.

(it's a meaningless  question to him, as  if to a child) Uh... in the, well, in the interests  of her family... you, Dr. Gruber,  you know, you can never tell what a  jury is going to do. St. Catherine's  a very well thought of institution.  Her doctors...
(glances at watch,  impatient) Her doctors killed her.
(a beat) I'm sorry...?
Her doctors murdered her. They gave  her the wrong anesthetic and they  put her in the hospital for life. (a beat) Her doctors murdered her.
Do you know who her doctors were?
I read the file. Yeah. Marx and  Towler. I know who they were.
The most respected...

(smiling) Whose side are you arguing...? I  thought that you wanted to do  something. I don't have any interest  in the woman's 'estate' -- No offense,  but we all know where the money's  going to... I have an interest in  the Hospital; and I don't want those  bozos working in the same shop as  me. They gave her the wrong  anesthetic. They turned the girl  into a vegetable. They killed her  and they killed her kid. You caught  'em. Now: how many others did they  kill?
A beat. Gruber discards end of a cigar. Takes a leather c from his suede jacket, extracts a new cigar. Offers one t Galvin.
You want a cigar?
Galvin takes one absently.
The hospital is owned by the  Archdioceses of...
What are they going to do? Not invite  me to their Birthday party...? (checks watch) Look, I gotta go. I have to be in  Cambridge...
Galvin, excited, is trying to light the cigar. His hand s badly. He has forgotten to bite off the end. He bites it, lights the cigar.
Well, well, when can we meet again.
I'd like to get a deposition..
Okay. I'll meet you here. Tuesday  night... I gotta go. You going my  way?
Galvin shakes his head.
Gruber opens door and walks out into the cold, into the  parking lot, followed by Galvin, who is lighting his ciga
We have to... we... we have to keep  you under wraps. Please don't, don't  discuss...
I understand.
...the case with anyone. And I'll  meet you Tuesday, and we'll go over  your testimony...
They stop before a 1950s very beautiful small Mercedes Se Gruber opens the door, gets into the plush red leather  interior, starts car, leaves door open, still talking to  Galvin.
Right. Seven o'clock. Here.
Galvin scribbles information in his appointment book.
Thank you...
...that's perfectly all right.
(beat) Uh, why, why are you doing this?
(thinks a second) To do right. Isn't that why you're  doing it?
Galvin is at the bar, smiling to himself. His drink is be refilled. To BARTENDER:
I want to buy you a drink.
Thanks, Franky.

Galvin looks around. A very attractive self-possessed YOU WOMAN is sitting in the crook of the bar across from him; she is intently perusing the newspaper and circling items with a felt pen. Galvin speaks to her:
Would you like a drink?
She looks up. Smiles.
I'd like an apartment.
Settle for a drink?
She gestures at her own full glass in front of her.
No. Thank you.
Galvin shrugs.
I had a very good day today.
(beat, smiles, downs  drink, gets up off  the stool, sincerely) I'm glad you did. Thank you. Good  night.
You're very welcome.
He watches her as she leaves the bar. He turns back to hi drink.
Well, well, well. Huh?
Yeah.
(sighs) It's a long road that has no turning.
That's for sure, Frank.

A shoddy one-and-a-half room bachelor apartment. Galvin,  beer and cigarettes on the table beside him. He is sittin on an armchair in the bedroom. A yellow legal pad in his  lap. He is talking on the phone softly, soothingly.

I'm going to the Archdiocese tomorrow  at two. I know you don't. I know you  don't... no, you're just following  your life. You have a life too...  you have to move out West. It doesn't  help you to stay here. Well... I'm  sure she knows you care for her.

His attention wanders to the legal pad in his lap. ANGLE - P.O.V. The legal pad. Spread on it a couple of Polaroids of Debo Ann in the nursing home. Below them, written on the pad,  large, "Dr. David Gruber. Ass't. Chief Anesthesiology, Ma Commonwealth. 'They killed her. And they killed her kid - Her doctors murdered her.'" The following figures are written on the pad: $150,000.00 written very large, circled, crossed out. $250,000.00  similarly circled and crossed out. $225,000.00 circled ma times.

(voice over; on phone) Well. Well. Well. Finally we're none  of us protected... we... we just  have to go on. To seek help where we  can... and go on... I know that you  love her... I know you're acting out  of love.
(into phone) As soon as I know... you give him my  respects too. Not at all. Not at  all... Good night. (beat) Well, bless you, too. Good night.
He hangs up phone, sighs. Lights a cigarette. Rotates his neck to loosen it up. Reaches to the table next to his be for the bottle to pour a drink.

His hand reaching for the bottle. On the table the photo a very beautiful blonde woman in a silver frame. She is t same woman we saw earlier in the news clip. She is on the deck of a sailboat, laughing. A pile of change on the tab a money clip, a rosary, and the wedding ring in the pile change.

Galvin looking at the photo in the silver frame next to h bed. He sighs deeply. Beat. Reaches up to the lamp above head and turns it off. He sits stiffly in the dark a mome then lets his head fall back to the chair.
Galvin, spruced up a bit, sitting on a bed, his briefcase his lap. Gazing at the unseen Deborah Ann Kaye in the dar ward. Silent. Beat. He looks in his briefcase, takes out file.

The file, labeled Deborah Ann Kaye. Galvin extracting the photo of the young mother romping with her two children; takes the yellow legal pad from his briefcase and puts it top of the picture (the figures crossed out; "Her doctors murdered her," etc.). We hear the door to the ward open and TWO IRISH WOMEN  gossiping.
Jimmy, I said, don't you go in your  pocket if there's nothing there...
...and what did he say...?
(spies Galvin, her  tone changes) ...Sir, you aren't allowed to be in  here...

Galvin sitting on the bed looking at Deborah Ann. He look up to the speaker. A slovenly Irish Nurse, who has come i the room and is standing by him. The other Nurse is frame in the doorway. Galvin is lost in thought.
You can't be in here.
(as if remembering  something, simply) I'm her attorney.
The Bishop from the waist up, sitting behind his beautifu desk. Compassionately:

It's a question of continuing values.  St. Catherine's -- to do the good  that she must do in the community  has to maintain the position that  she holds in the community. So we  have a question of balance. On the  one hand, the reputation, and, so,  the effectiveness of our hospital,  and two of her important doctors --  and, on the other hand, the rights  of your client.
Galvin seated across from the Bishop. A YOUNG PRIEST seat discreetly, attentively, across the room. Sherry glasses front of Galvin and the Bishop. Galvin drinking from his.
A young woman. In her prime...  deprived of... (searches for a word) ...life... sight... her family...  It's tragic. It's a tragic accident.
Galvin has been dreaming.
...nothing, of course, can begin to  make it right. But we must do what  we can. We must do all that we can.

He gestures to the Young Priest, who crosses the room,  extracts a sheet from a file folder, and places it before Galvin, who is sitting as if in a dream. The Bishop waits beat, not wanting to interrupt Galvin's reverie, then cat his eye and gestures down at the paper. Galvin glances do

The sheet: "I, Frank P. Galvin, duly appointed conservato for Deborah Ann Kaye, in consideration of Two Hundred Ten Thousand Dollars ($210,000.00) paid in hand to me this da by St. Catherine Laboure Hospital do hereby release from and all claims..."
Galvin and the Bishop as before. Galvin finishes reading, looks up.
Yes. We must try to make it right.
Beat. Galvin nods. Beat. Bishop nods discreetly to the Yo Priest who extracts Mount Blanc fountain pen from his poc holds it out to Galvin.
It's a generous offer, Mr. Galvin... (beat) ...nothing can make the woman well...  but we try to compensate... to make  a gesture...
How did you settle on the amount?
We thought it was just.
You thought it was just.
Yes.
Because it struck me how neatly  'three' went into the amount. Two  Hundred Ten Thousand. That would  mean I keep seventy.
That was our insurance company's  recommendation.
Yes. It would be.
A beat.
Nothing that we can do can make that  woman well.
And no one will know the truth.
What is the truth?

That that poor girl put her trust in  the hands of two men who took her  life, she's in a coma, her life is  gone. She has no family, she has no  home, she's tied to a machine, she  has no friends -- and the people who  should care for her: her Doctors,  and you, and me, have been bought  off to look the other way. We have  been paid to look the other way. I  came in here to take your money. (beat) I brought snapshots to show you. So  I could get your money. (to Young Priest,  waving away document) I can't take it. If I take it. If I  take that money I'm lost. I'm just  going to be a rich ambulance chaser. (beat; pleading for  understanding) I can't do it. I can't take it.
If we may discuss money, Mr. Galvin.  How is your law practice?
It's not too good. I've only got one  client.

Galvin, determined, coming down a corridor in the Courtho opens a door. CAMERA FOLLOWS him IN. The Lawyers Room. Ten or twelve AMBULANCE CHASERS waiting for clients. They all look up as he enters, then return to their reading,  phones, card games. CAMERA FOLLOWS him TO the corner of t room where MICKEY MORRISSEY is playing Gin with a CRONY.
I have to talk to you.
What do you want?
(dragging him up) Come on. Let's get a drink.
