They, uh, they got to my witness.
...and is that serious?
Galvin, suddenly focuses, starts for worktable.
I've got to work...
Do you want me to go...?
No, no, I'm just...
He stops, rubs his face...
Why don't you get some rest?
I've got to work.
You can't work if you can't think.  You get in bed. It's all right. I'll  stay here with you. It's all right.  Come on...
You're going to stay here...?
Yes.
A beat.
I'm only going to rest a little while.
She leads him into the bedroom.

Same room, Laura, dressed in Galvin's bathrobe, sitting i the easy chair next to his worktable, smoking a cigarette reading an old hard-cover novel. She looks up across the  room. ANGLE - P.O.V. The door to the bedroom, closed.
Laura sighs, takes a drag. Puts the book down on her lap. Sits, thinking.
Witness stand. DR. TOWLER, a distinguished man in his fif sitting on the stand. Concannon o.s. The doctor is ill-at ease; smiles nervously.
What is your name, please?
Dr. Robert Towler.
You were Deborah Ann Kaye's doctor...?
No, actually, she was referred to  me. She was Dr. Hagman's patient...
Don't equivocate. Be positive. Just  tell the truth.
The conference room. WIDE. Concannon's young lawyers taki notes as Concannon rehearses Dr. Towler, a Sony VTR being operated by one of them.
Whatever the 'truth' is, let's hear  that. You were her doctor.
Yes.
Say it.
I was her doctor.
You were the anesthesiologist at her  delivery May twelfth, nineteen  seventy...
...I was one of a group of...
Answer affirmatively. Simply. Keep  those answers to three words. You  weren't 'part of a group,' you were  her anesthesiologist. Isn't that  right?
Yes.
You were there to help Dr. Marx  deliver her baby. Were you not?
Yes.
Concannon starts to stroll a bit around the conference ro in back of the assembled assistants, by the large windows which offer a panoramic view of Boston.
Anything special about the case?
When she...
The young lawyer (BILLY), Concannon's right-hand assistan raises his hand to get Concannon's attention.
(to Dr. Towler,  correcting him) When 'Debby'... (to Young Lawyer) Thank you.
Young Lawyer nods, makes a notation in his pad.
Thank you. When Debby...
(switching his tack) Dr. Towler, who was in the operating  room with you?
Ms. Nevins, nurse-anesthetist; Dr.  Marx, of course...
He nods toward Dr. Marx who is in the audience, who nods  back.
Mary Rooney, the obstetrical nurse...
What did these people do when her  heart stopped?
We went to Code Blue...
'Code Blue,' what does that mean...?
It's a common medical expression,  it's a crash program to restore the  heartbeat. Dr. Marx cut an airway in  her trachea, to get her oxygen, her  and the baby... Ms. Nevins...
Why wasn't she getting oxygen...?
Well, many reasons, actually...
Tell me one?
She'd aspirated vomitus into her  mask...
She THREW UP IN HER MASK. Let's cut  the bullshit. Say it: She THREW UP  IN HER MASK.
A beat.
She threw up in her mask.
Concannon nods to the Young Lawyer, who is conscientiousl taking notes.
...and her heart stopped and she  wasn't getting oxygen.
That's right.
And what did your team do...
Well, we...
...You brought thirty years of medical  experience to bear. Isn't that what  you did?
Yes.
...A patient riddled with  complications, questionable  information on her, on her admitting  form...
...We did everything we could...
...to save her and to save the baby.  Is that...
Yes!
You reached down into death. Now,  isn't that right?
(getting overcome) My God, we tried to save her... You  can't know... You can't know...
(changing tactics;  soothing) Tell us.
Beat. Dr. Towler sighs. He begins to speak.
People coming out of a just-arrived train.
Galvin watching them, he has a large boutonniere on his l The departing PASSENGERS stream past him. An elderly BLAC MAN passes him by, turns and comes back to him.
Mr. Galvin?
Galvin turns. He is taken aback. He registers who it must be.
Dr. Thompson...?
It was good of you to meet...
Galvin cuts him off, takes his bag.
Thank you for coming.
They shake hands. They start...
into the station. The CAMERA TRACKING BEFORE them. As Gal passes a wastebasket, he deposits his boutonniere.
I have some errands to run, and then  I thought we'd spend the evening...
(nodding) That's what I'd planned to...
I'm going to take you to the home to  see the girl...
(tapping his briefcase,  referring to his  files) From what I've seen, Mr. Galvin, you  have a very good case...
(distracted; thinking  ahead) Yes. Yes. I think so. I hope you'll  be comfortable. I'm putting you up  at my...
...I made a reservation at...
...apartment. (stops) No, no. Please. You don't know who  we're dealing with, I, please believe  me, they...
...What difference would...
These people play very rough. They  don't want to lose this case. There's  a lot of pressure they can bring to  bear, I...
(smiles) There's nothing they can do to me.
Galvin starts them walking again.
Please, Sir. Please. Humor me.
They have arrived outside at a bank of cabs.

We'll spend the evening together,  I'll put you up, you'll be very  comfortable. Please. (hands Dr. Thompson  an envelope) That's my address. The key is in it. (leans forward to  cabbie) 1225 Commonwealth. (to Dr. Thompson) Treat the place as your own. Please  don't tell anyone you're here, I'll  see you this evening. Thank you, and  thank you for coming.
He puts Dr. Thompson's bag into the cab. Dr. Thompson  hesitates, gets into the cab. As the cab pulls out, CAMERA FOLLOWS Galvin TO a bank of  phones outside the station.
Galvin at the phone.
(Claire, on phone) Mr. Galvin's...
Let me talk to Mickey.
(on phone) Yeah? How's our new witness?
D'you find the obstetric nurse?
She's workin' the late shift at the  Hospital. She's at home now, I'm  going over there to talk to...
Gimme the address. I'm gonna go.  We're going to need her.
Names on bells. One of them is ROONEY, M. 2D.
Galvin standing by the bell. Rings it. Beat. The door is  buzzed, he walks into the vestibule, past mailboxes, up t stairs.
Door opens, MARY ROONEY, a tough-looking woman in nurse w opens the door.
Galvin in hall, CAMERA FOLLOWS him TO the door.
I'm Joe Galvin, I'm representing  Deborah Ann Kaye, case against St.  Catherine Laboure.
I told the guy I didn't want to talk  to...
I'll just take a minute. Deborah Ann  Kaye. You know what I'm talking about.  The case is going to trial. Our chief  witness is a Dr. David Gruber, you  know who he is?
No.

He's the Assistant Chief of  Anesthesiology, Massachusetts  Commonwealth. He says your doctors,  Towler and Marx, put my girl in the  hospital for life. And we can prove  that. What we don't know is why.  What went on in there? In the O.R.  That's what we'd like to know.  Something went wrong. And you know  what it was. They gave her the wrong  anesthetic. What happened? The phone  rang... someone got distracted...  what?
...you got your doctor's testimony.  Why do you need me?
I want someone who was in the O.R.  We're going to win the case, there's  no question of that. It's just a  matter of how big...
I've got nothing to say to you.
You know what happened.
Nothing happened.
Then why aren't you testifying for  their side?
She starts to close the door. He stops her.
I can subpoena you, you know. I can  get you up there on the stand.
And ask me what?
Who put my client in the hospital  for life.
I didn't do it, Mister.
Who are you protecting, then?
Who says that I'm protecting anyone?
I do. Who is it? The Doctors. What  do you owe them?
I don't owe them a goddamn thing.
Then why don't you testify?
(beat) You know, you're pushy, fella...
You think I'm pushy now, wait 'til I  get you on the stand...

Well, maybe you better do that, then. (starts to close door;  stops) You know you guys are all the same.  You don't care who gets hurt. You're  a bunch of whores. You'd do anything  for a dollar. You got no loyalty...  no nothing... you're a bunch of  whores.
A young LAWYER on the phone, silent, nodding, taking note He holds up his hand to someone indicating "Almost done.  I'll be right with you."
Concannon, in overcoat, about to go out, surrounded by an entourage of secretaries and ASSISTANTS in overcoats, wai on him.
Concannon and the Young Attorney. The Young Attorney into phone, "Thank you." He hangs up, starts reading from his  notes to Concannon:

His name is Dr. Lionel Thompson.  City College of New York, Class of  twenty-six. Bachelor of Science; New  York College of Medicine; sixteenth  in a class of twenty-two. Nineteen  seventy-six got a courtesy  appointment, staff of anesthesiology,  Easthampton Hospital for Women. Never  married. Has no honors or degrees of  any weight. Since nineteen seventy- five he's testified in twenty-eight  court cases, twelve malpractice. (smiles, saving his  best 'til last) And he's black.

(beat; stern) I'm going to tell you how you handle  the fact that he's black. You don't  touch it. You don't mention it. You  treat him like anybody else. Neither  better or worse. (smiles) And you get a black lawyer to sit at  our table. Okay...?
Yessir.
Good. What else do you do?
...get the records of his testimony  in the twelve malpractice cases.
Concannon nods, meaning "that is correct." He turns, exit with his ENTOURAGE. Over his shoulder:
Do it. We'll be at Locke-Obers.
Dr. Thompson in shirt sleeves, attentive, stands against sideboard. Mickey Morrissey, seated, in an armchair. Grilling him.
They gave her the wrong anesthetic.
Why is that?
(starting on reciting  a list) Her sister said she ate one hour  prior to admittance... she...
...that's what the sister said. The  chart said she ate nine hours prior  to...
...she went in complaining of stomach  cramps. Good doctor would have doubted  the information on the chart.
Is that what a good doctor would do?  How old are you, please?
I am seventy-four years old.
What qualifies you as an expert in  anesthetics?
I am on the staff of...

Easthampton Hospital for Women. Excuse  me, what is that, a joke? Let me  tell you something, Doctor, those  men at Catherine Laboure. Men who  are known not only in this city, but  the world, were trying to save a  woman's life. They were there, and  here you are, four years later, read  some hospital report, and say...
...I made a detailed physical  examination of the patient, Sir,  yesterday evening, I...
Mickey drops his belligerent attitude. Turns to someone b him.
The two men, Galvin standing behind Mickey, smoking. He n
(to Dr. Thompson,  casually) She getting good care over there?
Actually, yes. It's by no means bad,  I...
(grilling him again) Then what good would it do to ruin  the reputation of two men, to help a  girl whose life's not going to be  changed in the least? You know what  CODE BLUE means?
'Code Blue'...
It's a common medical term.
Mickey half-turns to Galvin, shrugs minutely, meaning, "W in trouble."
Hotel room door SEEN from the inside. The handle starts to turn.

Galvin coming through the door. He looks at Laura, tiredly closes the door behind him, ha up his coat in the closet, moves into the room. As Galvin walks into the room, the CAMERA PRECEDES him and TURNS so that WE NOW SEE them BOTH.
We're going to lose.
A beat. Galvin looks out the window and then looks back t Laura.
Do you think it's my fault?
Isn't there something you...
That's not the question. It's over. (beat) Do you think that it's my fault? If  I'd... if I'd... I never should have  taken it. There was no way that I  was going to win.
You're talking like a drunk.
That's what I am.
Beat.
And it's over...?
Yes.
Well, then what are you doing here?
I... do you want me to leave?
You do what you want. You want to  leave... You want to go kill yourself?
You want me to tell you it's your  fault? It probably is. What are you  going to do about it? (beat) I thought it's not over till the  jury comes in.
Who told you that?
You told me so. Maybe you'd get some  sympathy. You came to the wrong place.
And what makes you so tough?
Maybe I'll tell you later.
Is there going to be a later...?
Not if you don't grow up...
If I don't 'grow up...'
You're like a kid, you're coming in  here like it's Saturday night, you  want me to say that you've got a  fever -- you don't have to go to  school...
(shakes head sadly) You, you don't under...
Oh, yes, I do, Joe. Believe me. You  say you're going to lose. Is it my  fault? Listen! The damned case doesn't  start until tomorrow and already  it's over for you!
It's over!
What is your wife's picture doing by  the side of your...
What is that to you...?
What would you like it to be to me...?  I, I, I can't invest in failure.
Galvin gets up hurriedly.
Excuse me, I've...
He hurries out of the room. CAMERA FOLLOWS him into the  bathroom, he shuts the door, his chest heaves convulsivel He can't catch his breath... Beat. We hear a knock on the door.
Joe... (beat) Joe...
(screaming) Stop pressuring me...
The door opens, Galvin is still trying to catch his breat Laura enters.
You're pressuring yourself...
(shaking head, utterly  denying her) No... no...
Yes. (beat) We've all got to let go.
Galvin coming down the corridor with Sally Doneghy. They  stop by a door on which the card reads: "PART III. DEBORA

head_text.subj: ANN KAYE V. ST. CATHERINE LABOURE HOSPITAL ET AL."

text: They enter the courtroom. CAMERA FOLLOWS them in. The roo one-quarter filled. Concannon at the defense table with t Defendants, a Black Lawyer, entourage. Galvin stops.
(to Sally) I'm going to do the best I can for  you and your sister. I know what it  means to you. Believe me... (beat) It means that much to me.
He turns away, walks toward the front of the courtroom,  glances toward the jury box. ANGLE - P.O.V. The Jury, somber, controlled, dignified.
Galvin continuing to the defense table, Mickey Morrissey  already seated, studying notes on a yellow legal pad. Gal sits. Mickey looks up.
How are you holding up?
I'm swell.
And all we've got is a witch doctor!
Yeah.
The BAILIFF enters, some SPECTATORS, knowing the routine, start getting to their feet.
Look at it this way: it's refreshing  every time a Doctor takes the stand  he's not a Jew.
We hear the Bailiff's "All rise."
The COURTROOM getting to its feet as JUDGE WILLIAM B. HOY enters. The Bailiff, as the Judge sits:

Hear ye, hear ye, hear ye, all persons  having anything to do before the  Honorable, the Justices of the  Superior Court now sitting at Boston  within and for the County of Suffolk,  draw near, give your attendance and  you shall be heard. God save the  Commonwealth of Massachusetts.
The Courtroom is seated. JUDGE motions to the CLERK, who  stands and reads:
Deborah Ann Kaye versus St. Catherine  Laboure, Robert S. Towler, M.D. and  Sheldon F. Marx, M.D.
GALVIN at Plaintiff's table, looking down at notes.
Is the Plaintiff ready?
(looking up) Ready, your Honor.
Defense...?
Ready for the Defense, your Honor.
The Courtroom. P.O.V. JUDGE.
Let's begin.
Galvin gets to his feet. Walks over to the JURY. Looks at them, appraising. He pauses as before a great effort. Tak a breath. Exhales.

It's a terrible thing to sit in  judgment. So much rides on it. I  know that you've thought, 'How can I  be pure. How can I be impartial  without being cold. How can I be  merciful and still be just?' And I  know that most of you have said some  sort of prayer this morning to be  helped. To judge correctly. We have  the reputation of two men. Two well  respected doctors and a renowned  hospital before us. And with those  two respected men we have my client,  Deborah Ann Kaye... (beat) ...who was deprived of sight, of  locomotion, hearing, speech, of  everything, in short, which  constitutes her life. (beat) We are going to prove she was deprived  through negligence. (beat) Through the negligence of those  respected men. We will show: One...
A lavishly appointed corridor. Alito and BILLY, the YOUNG LAWYER from Concannon's office, walking slowly down the  corridor.
Why did he go to see Mary Rooney?
She's the only nurse who isn't  testifying for the Doctors.
What did he find?
Nothing.
How good's your intelligence?
Very good.
And so what is the rest of his case  aside from Dr. Thompson?
As far as we know, nothing.
Alito nods, they stop outside a large double door.
Thank Mr. Concannon for me. Please  tell him I'll see him at his office.
Alito knocks on the door. The door is opened by a YOUNG  PRIEST. Alito nods to the Young Lawyer, enters the Bishop's study The door is closed behind him.
The jury box. One JUROR leans over and makes a whispered  comment to another. The SECOND JUROR nods, inclines his h toward the witness box.
DR. Thompson on the stand. Composed, waiting. Concannon  consulting his notes.
Dr. Thompson, just so the Jury knows,  you never treated Deborah Ann Kaye.  Is that correct?
That is correct. I was engaged to  render an opinion.
Engaged to render an opinion. For a  price. Is that correct? You're being  paid to be here today?
Just as you are, Sir...
Are you board-certified in  anesthesiology, Doctor?
No, I am not. It's quite common in  New York State...
...I'm sure it is, but this is  Massachusetts, Doctor. Certified in  Internal Medicine?
No.
Neurology?
No.
Orthopedics?
I'm just an M.D.
Do you know Dr. Robert Towler...?
I know of him.
How is that?
Through, through his book.
What book is that?
Meth... Methodology and Technique...
...of Anesthesiology?
'Methodology and Techniques of  Anesthesiology.' Yes.
How old are you?
I am seventy-four years old.
Uh-huh. Still practice a lot of  medicine?
I'm on the staff of...
Yes, we've heard that. Doctor: you  testify quite a bit against other  physicians? Isn't that right? You,  you're available for that? When you're  paid to be there?
Sir. Yes. When a thing is wrong...  as in this case, I am available. I  am seventy-four years old, I am not  board-certified.
I have been practicing medicine for  forty-six years and I know when an  injustice has been done.
Do you, indeed. I'll bet you do.  Fine. Fine. We'll save the court the  time. We will admit the Doctor as an  'expert witness,' fine.
Concannon sits.

(in undertone, to  Bailiff) Do we have time this morning to... (glances at watch,  Bailiff nods to him) All right. Mr. Galvin, you want to  continue now, or we can resume with  Dr. Thompson this afternoon.
(rising) Thank you, your Honor, I'll continue.  Dr. Thompson. Did you examine Deborah  Ann Kaye last night at The Northern  Chronic Care Facility?
I did.
Objection.
Sustained. Yes. The witness will  confine his testimony to review of  the hospital records.
What?
(patronizing) I believe that's the law... is it  not, Mr. Galvin...?
A beat.
Dr. Thompson. From your review of  the hospital records of May twelfth  nineteen seventy-six.
In your opinion, what happened to  Deborah Ann Kaye?
Cardiac arrest. During delivery her  heart stopped. When the heart stops  the brain's deprived of oxygen. You  get brain damage. That is why she's  in the state she's in today.
Now, Dr. Towler's testified that  they restored the heartbeat within  three or four minutes. In your opinion  is his estimate correct?
It's my opinion it took him much  longer. Nine... ten minutes. There's  too much brain damage.
The Judge leans over.
(to Dr. Thompson) Are you saying that a failure to  restore the heartbeat within nine  minutes in itself constitutes bad  medical practice?
Well...
Your Honor!
He has shouted unconsciously; the whole Courtroom turns t look at him.
Yes, Mr. Galvin?
If I may be permitted to question my  own witness in my own way...

I'd just like to get to the point,  Mr. Galvin. Let's not waste these  people's time. Answer the question,  Mr. Witness. Please. Would a nine  minute lapse in restoring the  heartbeat in and of itself be  negligence?
I... in that small context I would  have... I would have to say 'no.'
Then you're saying there's no  negligence, based on my question?
I... given the limits of your  question, that's correct.
The Doctors were not negligent.
(beat) I... um...
The Judge shrugs, meaning, "Well then what in the hell ar we doing here?"
Galvin, furious.
The Judge and Witness.
Thank you.
The Witness starts to step down. Galvin strides over to h and speaks to the Judge.
I'm not through with the witness,  your Honor. With all due respect if  you are going to try my case for me  I would appreciate it if you wouldn't  lose it.
The Judge stands, furious.
Thank you. I think that's enough for  this morning. I'll see the Plaintiff's  Counsel in my chambers. Now, please.
The Courtroom rises. The Bailiff is heard, "All rise, cou is adjourned until one o'clock."
Galvin, furious, standing against the wall. The Judge com in from his own entrance, shucking his robe. Equally angr
I got a letter from the Judge  Advocate's office on you today, fella,  you're on your way out... They should  have kicked you out on that  Lillibridge case. Now this is it  today.
I'm an attorney on trial before the  bar. Representing my client. My  client, do you understand? You open  your mouth and you're losing my case  for me.
Listen to me, fella...

No, no, you listen to me. All I wanted  in this case is an even shake. You  rushed me into court in five days...  my star witness disappears, I can't  get a continuance, and I don't give  a damn. I'm going up there and I'm  going to try it. Let the Jury decide.  They told me Sweeney he's a hard- ass, he's a defendant's judge. I  don't care. I said, the hell with  it. The hell with it. I'll take my  chances he'll be fair.
Galvin is pacing. Beat.
(conciliatory) Galvin, look, many years ago...
And don't give me this shit, 'I was  a lawyer, too.' 'Cause I know who  you were. You couldn't hack it as a  lawyer. You were Bag Man for the  Boys and you still are. I know who  you are.
(beat; barely  controlling anger) Are you done?

Damn right I'm done. I'm going to  ask for a mistrial and I'm going to  request that you disqualify yourself  from sitting on this case. I'm going  to take a transcript to the State  and ask that they impeach your ass.
You aren't going to get a mistrial,  boy. We're going back this afternoon,  we're going to try this case to an  end. Now you get out of here before  I call the Bailiff and have you thrown  in jail.
Galvin walking down the corridor, having just come from t Judge's Chambers. Sally Doneghy comes up to him.
What does it mean? (beat) I... I mean we, you have other  tactics...
We, yes. Yes. They, they present  their side, and I get the same chance.  To cross-examine... to... to...
Are we going to win? (beat, desperately  needing to trust) We have, you know, other tactics,  though...
Yes.

She nods. Beat. Walks off. Galvin turns to the open door the Courtroom, through which the SPECTATORS are reenterin for the afternoon session. Mickey is standing by the door he catches Galvin's eye. They look at each other a moment
Dr. Towler on the witness stand. Concannon walking away f him.
No further questions.
Galvin at the Plaintiff's table, hastily scribbling notes he looks up. Gets to his feet, walks over to Dr. Towler i the witness box, the CAMERA MOVES WITH him.
Dr. Towler...
Yes.
You have a record of what happened  in the operating room...
Yes, that's correct.
...there are notations every thirty  seconds...
Yes.
...of the procedures...
Yes, the roving nurse...
But those notations stop... (consults notes) ...Four-and-one-half minutes after  Deborah Ann Kaye's...
We, we were rather busy...
Four-and-one-half minutes after her  heart stopped. (beat) And they resume seven minutes...
As I've said we had some more...
...they start again three minutes  earlier...
We had rather more important things  on our mind than taking notes. (beat) We were trying to restore her...
What happened in those three...
...we were trying to restore her  heartbeat.
What happened in those three  minutes...?
(beat; controls himself) We'd gone to 'Code Blue,' we were  administering electro...
Why did it take that long to get her  heartbeat...
Objection, we've...
...to get her heartbeat back...?
We've touched on this, his own witness  has said...
(overriding him) ...almost nine minutes... causing  brain damage.
Your Honor...! Your Honor...
Brain damage could have been... it  didn't necessarily take nine minutes,  it could have been caused in two...
Wait, wait, wait, you're saying that  her brain damage could have been  caused by her being deprived of oxygen  for two minutes...?
Yes.
(contemptuous) Huh. And why is that?
Because she was anemic. (beat) It's right there on her chart. Her  brain was getting less oxygen  anyway...
Galvin is struck dumb. He has just made a terrible error. He looks at Mickey. ANGLE - P.O.V. Mickey looks at Galvin. He shakes his head sadly.
The last of the spectators coming out of the court. Galvi and Dr. Thompson are standing there.
I didn't do too well for you.
No, you did fine.
I'm afraid that's not true. (beat) Will you want me to stay on till  Monday?
No. No thank you, Doctor. You go  home.
You know... sometimes people can  surprise you. Sometimes they have a  great capacity to hear the truth.
Yes... I... yes.
They shake hands. Dr. Thompson walks off. Stops.
You sure you don't want me to stay  on.
No. No. Thank you. You go home.
Mickey walks out of the courtroom arranging papers in his briefcase.
I'm going back to the office.
He walks off leaving Galvin standing there alone. Laura c out of the courtroom. Tentatively, she looks around. Comes up to him.
Laura and Galvin walking.
Is it over?
No.
What are you going to do?
I don't have a goddamned idea.
Galvin pacing. Mickey seated. Morose.
Okay. What do you do when you don't  have a witness?
(reciting a catechism;  dispiritedly) You use their witness.
That's right.
I think we tried that. The case is  over.
Galvin continues pacing. He will not hear what was just s

And how the fuck... You broke the  first law that they taught you in  law school. You never ask a question  you don't know the answer to. (beat) Frankie, wake up. You got your own  expert witness says there was no  negligence. It's over. Period.  There'll be no other cases...
Galvin turns on him, animal-like.
There are no other cases. This is  the case. (beat) Now you decide... (beat) Are you in or out...?
Soft, dim lights. Concannon sitting on a couch. He holds red-backed file document. His listener is unseen.

I know how you feel. I know you don't  believe me, but I do. I'm going to  tell you something I learned when I  was your age. I had prepared a case.  Mr. White asked me, 'How did you  do.' (beat) I said, 'I've done my best.' He said,  'They don't pay you to do your best.  They pay you to win.' (beat) That's what pays for this office. (beat) And that's what pays for the pro  bono work that we do for the poor.  And for the kind of law that you  want to practice. And that's what  pays for your clothes and my whiskey,  and the leisure that we have to sit  back and discuss philosophy. (beat) As we're doing tonight. (beat) We're paid to win the case.
Laura sitting across from him, impassive.
You finished your marriage. You wanted  to come back and practice law. You  wanted to come back to the world.
A beat. He hands the red-backed document to her.
stamped CONCANNON, BARKER, WHITE. Confidential. Eyes only
Welcome back.

A lonely middle-class hotel corridor. HOLD. HOLD. Laura,  tired, enters the corridor from the side and proceeds awa from the CAMERA. The CAMERA FOLLOWS her to her door. She  stops, takes out her key, tiredly opens the door.
Laura opening the door, looks down, sees something, bends down to pick it up. Straightens up.
A hotel envelope, The Hotel Lincoln - Boston, Mass. on th letterhead. Laura's hands open the message, take out a sh of yellow legal paper.
Laura closes the door behind her, she does not turn on th light, walks over to a couch by the window, sits down, al the while reading the paper by the outside light. She low the paper to her lap.
The legal sheet. It reads, handwritten: Laura. I'm going to try. When this is over can we go away Joe.
Mickey on his feet, pacing. Galvin at a blackboard on whi is written, "Dr. Towler. Dr. Marx. Admitting Form.  Anaesthesia." Etc.
Why doesn't Mary Rooney testify?
Mickey shakes his head.
Are you with me... are you awake...?
Yeah. I'm awake.
Rooney's protecting someone. Who is  she protecting?
The Doctors.
She's protecting the Doctors she'd  be up there on the stand...
(listlessly) Read me what she said.
Galvin flips through his notes. Reads.
'You guys are a bunch of whores...  uh... loyalty... you don't care who  gets hurt... you don't have any  loyalty...'
...one of the other nurses?
Who? They're all testifying. Everybody  who was in the O.R.'s going to take  the stand.
All right. Who wasn't in the O.R.?
What difference can that make...?  All right...
He starts checking the charts. Sighs. "This is useless...
Uh... the admitting nurse...
What did she do?
She didn't do anything. She took the  patient's history and signed the  charts. 'K.C.' (looks in the notes  for what the initials  signify) 'Kathy Costello...'
The 'History'...?
(explaining) How old are you, how many children...  when did you last eat...
Mary Rooney and another Nurse walking down the corridor  carrying foil-covered dishes of food, chatting.
Galvin watching them from behind a corner.
The Nurses come to the corner, Galvin walks past. "Notice Rooney. Stops.
Miss Rooney. Oh. Listen. (beat) I understand what you are doing. And  I want you to know it's all right.
He nods, starts off in the direction he was going in.
What are you talking about?
Galvin turns, confused. Goes back to her. Warmly,  conciliatory.
About Kathy Costello. (beat) I understand, and I don't blame you  for shielding her.
A beat. Mary Rooney motions the other Nurse to go away. She steps closer to Galvin.
I spoke to her, and everything is  all right.
I, what are you talking about? I  talked to her this morning, and she  said...
(nods) She told me.
(credulous) She did?
I just saw her.
In New York?
What?
You saw Kat in New York... (beat) ...or is she in town? Is she in  town...?
Beat. It occurs to her that she's been duped, as Galvin s off hurriedly down the hall.

Laura. SEEN from the back, walking down the corridor. CAM FOLLOWS her. She stops outside Galvin's door. She turns. We SEE she is carrying a tray of coffee containers. She o door. CAMERA FOLLOWS her INTO the office. Mickey is on th phone in the vestibule, Galvin is on the phone in his off He is just hanging up.
Thank you. I'm sorry.
Laura starts distributing coffee. Galvin shouts to Mickey the far room.
We don't have anything from the Nurse  Association?
The broad has disappeared...
The Hospital...?
Laura goes into Galvin's office with coffee. CAMERA FOLLO her.
No records since she quit in '76.  She quit two weeks after the incident.
Laura hands coffee to Galvin.
Thank you.
I have to talk to you.
(to Mickey) Call the A.M.A. (to Laura) ...I can't talk now. (to Mickey) ...tell them you're Dr. Somebody...  you have to find this nurse...
...yeah... good...
...you need some old forms that she  had... somebody's dying...

Galvin picks up the telephone. Looks down to telephone bo in front of him, open on desk. ANGLE - P.O.V. New York City telephone directory. Two columns of COSTELL Thirty of them crossed off. Galvin on the phone.
Hello, Mrs. Costello...
Sorry to bother you so late.
Laura goes over to the couch, sits. Lights a cigarette.
This is Mr. Goldberg in Accounting.  We have some money here for you...  This is the Mrs. Costello that used  to be a nurse? (beat) I'm sorry. I think we have our records  mixed up.
Laura sitting on the couch. Tense. Smoking.
Are you related to Kathy Costello,  the R.N.?... I'm sorry...
We hear Mickey on his phone.
Hello, this is Dr. Dorchester in  Boston. This is an emergency. A nurse  left my employ...
Laura on the couch. Galvin dialing the phone. Mickey HALF SEEN in the next room.
...four years ago...
Hello. This is Mr. Dorchester in  Records. We're looking for Kathy  Costello...

(voice over; in the  other room, shouting) I need a cigarette! (resumes on-the-phone  tone) She left my office four years ago,  we're looking for a chart... (covers phone; again  shouts) I need a cigarette...

Laura looks around the desk, picks up one then another pa crushes them, empty. She nods to herself, picks up her co off the couch in the anteroom, and starts down the hall. Going through the door, she turns, looks back. ANGLE - P.O.V. Galvin in the inner office, on the phone.
Thank you. I'll hold.
He looks up. Sees Laura, gives her a half-smile.

Near the cash register of an all-night diner in the busin district, the deserted streets outside. Laura -- standing next to a wall phone, exhausted. She is handed a cardboar tray with three coffees on it and two packs of Pall Malls and some change by the Proprietor. She takes the change a turns her head to look at the telephone.
Mickey asleep on the couch, coffee containers around him, ashtray full of butts. Beat. We hear a telephone being di
Galvin, exhausted, smoking, on the telephone.

Hello. This is Ross Williams. I'm  calling from California. I'm sorry.  I know it's late in the East, but  this is an emergency. May I please  speak to Kathy Costello? (beat) I'm sorry. My records must be  confused. This is the family of Kathy  Costello...? Please excuse it.

He hangs up. Reaches for a bottle of whiskey on his desk. Pours a shot into a glass. Downs it. His attention is cau by something across the room. ANGLE - P.O.V. Laura asleep on the couch, covered in Galvin's overcoat.
Galvin looks gratefully at her. He begins dialing the pho
A small bundle of mail is pushed through the vertical slo and falls to the floor.

Interior office. Early morning. Galvin asleep with his he on his desk. Mickey asleep in a chair. Laura asleep on th couch, covered with Galvin's overcoat. Galvin wakes up,  startled by the sound of the mail dropping. He picks up t phone mechanically. He realizes it is morning and he has  been asleep. He replaces phone. He surveys the office. Dead, resigned. He closes the phone book. He reaches in a pack of cigarettes on the desk. It is empty. He roots in ashtray for a long butt. This disgusts him. He rejects it Rubs his eyes. Gets up. Goes to the window, stares out. L back at the scene in his office. It is over. He stands by Laura and looks down at her, he looks at Mic He has let them down. He goes to a cabinet under the lawb and takes out a bottle of whiskey and a water glass. He w into the anteroom. Sighs, sits on the couch near the door Glances at the several letters that have just fallen thro the slot. He pours a half-tumbler full of whiskey, and dr it. He refills the tumbler. He absently picks up the mail and starts mechanically sorting through it. He stops at a official-looking piece. ANGLE - P.O.V. The letter, return address MASSACHUSETTS BAR ASSOCIATION. URGENT. He lethargically opens the letter. On Bar Association  letterhead, it reads: "You are directed to appear on Janu 15th to show cause why you should not be disbarred. You a permitted to be represented by counsel of your choice, an

Galvin reading the letter. He crumbles it and throws it i the wastebasket. He looks at the next letter and skims it into the wastebasket. He looks at the next letter and sto ANGLE - P.O.V. It is a phone bill.
Galvin hurrying up the steps of the tenement. CAMERA FOLL him into the vestibule. It is Mary Rooney's tenement.
He stops by the mailboxes, bends over to read the names. ANGLE - P.O.V. The mailboxes: Swoboda; Murch; M. Rooney.

Galvin straightens, looks around the vestibule, takes hea letter opener from his jacket pocket and pries open the R mailbox. He extracts letters and rifles through them. ANGLE - P.O.V. Mary Rooney's phone bill.
Galvin in an old-fashioned sit-down phonebooth in a drugs He is dialing the phone, holding the phone bill. The oper answers, he starts dropping change into the slot.

The phone bill opened. It reads, "Rooney, Mary A. 263 Chu Street, Arlington, Mass." Various local charges. One call Chicago. One call to Fort Lauderdale. Eight calls to New  York. The calls to New York are circled in pen.
(voice over; on phone) Hello.
Galvin on the phone.
Hello, I'm calling from...
If you're selling something, I'm  late for work...
I'm calling from Professional Nurse  Quarterly...
From the magazine?
This is Mr. Wallace in Subscriptions?
How come you're calling me from...?
This is Miss Costello...?
Yes. Price...
Pardon?
Kathy Price.
We find that your subscription  lapsed...
(laughs) My subscription lapsed three years  ago...
That's why I'm calling, Miss Price...
Missus...
We have a renew-your-subscription  offer...
We get it at work. We get the magazine  at work.
Yes, we know that you do. I have it  in my files. That's at the Manhattan  Health Center...
No. At Chelsea Childcare. Okay. Look,  call me Monday, hey? I'm late for  work.
Galvin scribbles on pad as we hear Kathy hanging up. "Kat Price. Chelsea Childcare."

Galvin hurrying across the lobby. Stops by DO IT YOURSELF SHUTTLE TICKET COUNTER. Takes form, starts to write on it ANGLE - P.O.V. The form "BOSTON - NEW YORK SHUTTLE. SELF SERVICE TICKET. Galvin filling in his name and address in pencil.
Laura asleep on the couch. Mickey asleep on the other cou The phone is ringing. She wakes up. Looks around. Goes  groggily to phone, answers.
(on phone) Hello? Mr. Gal... where are you...?
Mickey wakes up, looks around.

You're going to New York? I... you're  kidding... Because I'm going to New  York. (beat) I just got a call. I have to go sign  papers. About my divorce. I... good.  Frank. We'll meet there. All right?
Mickey has woken up. Swings his feet to the floor. Picks a pack of cigarettes. Crushes it. It is empty.
Can we meet there, Joe?
Mickey gets to his feet.
(to Laura) You got a cigarette...?
She shrugs, "I don't know..."
At the Beacon. On Fifty-third  Street... we can spend the night.

Mickey has gone over to Laura's purse. Opens it, rummagin Comes up with a pack of cigarettes. He sees something in purse. Stops. ANGLE - P.O.V. The open purse. The red-backed legal form. The letterhead reads, "CONCANNON, BARKER, WHITE," stamped huge across it black: "CONFIDENTIAL. EYES ONLY!!!" Mickey takes out the  form, turns page. It reads, "Report on Joseph Galvin," li haunts, habits, and is heavily notated in various types o pen and pencil.
(on phone) At around four...?
Mickey replacing the form and the cigarettes. He re-close the purse. He turns to her. She has seen nothing.
I feel the same way, Joe... I'll see  you this afternoon?
She hangs up.
You got any cigarettes?

Two very young children walk across a play area. The door the play area opens and Joe Galvin, in overcoat, comes in He looks around the room, starts to walk across it. CAMERA PANS WITH him to REVEAL a woman, KATHY, who is  comforting a crying child. Galvin walks over to her. Stan a respectful distance away. She sees him watching her, lo up.
Hi.
Hi. How are you doing?
She nods, happy to be working with the child.
I've been meaning to come in a long  time.
You live in the neighborhood?
Uh-huh. My nephew's going to be  staying with us in a few months, so  I stopped by.
How old is he?
Four. You're great with these kids.
She beams, caught unprepared in something that is a great point of pride with her.
Thank you.
You're really... (stops, remembering  something) You, are you the one they told me  was the nurse?
Who told you that?
(gestures back at the  office, vaguely) Mrs...
Mrs. Simmonds.
Yes.
(very serious, correct) I used to be a nurse.
That's a wonderful profession. My  daughter-in-law's a nurse. What did  you do, stop?
Kathy is lost in thought. This is obviously a very painfu subject for her. Beat.
Yes.
Galvin, getting involved in a serious conversation, takes off his overcoat, he is going to stay awhile.
How come you stopped?

She is traumatized by the question. The casual conversati has become immediate and painful. She opens her mouth to  speak, then stops, staring at Galvin. He doesn't know wha she is staring at... something on his jacket. He looks do ANGLE - KATHY'S P.O.V. The shuttle ticket, BOSTON - NEW YORK, stuck in the lapel pocket of Galvin's suitcoat.
Kathy and Galvin. She realizes why he is there. She start to cry quietly.
(beat; gently dropping  his pretense) Will you help me?
The restaurant fairly deserted after the lunch crowd. Emp tables -- crisp linen, Laura alone at a table, watching t door, an untouched cup of coffee in front of her.
The doorman opens the door of a cab.
Mickey Morrissey standing in an alcove under the marquee, looking out at the street. ANGLE - P.O.V. The street. Pedestrians. Joe Galvin comes walking hurried smiling, down the street.
Mickey starting down the steps, intercepts Galvin. Galvin looks up, surprised.
What the hell are you doing here?
We got to talk.
He is moving Galvin off down the sidewalk, away from the  Hotel. CAMERA STAYS STILL, and their voices get fainter a they move away.
What are you doing in New York...?
Come on, we'll get a cup of coffee...

They continue walking. We cannot hear them. Galvin is bec agitated. He stops Mickey, stands there, Mickey very sad, Galvin incredulous, talking to him. Mickey nods. Galvin starts hurriedly back down the street toward the H
LONG SHOT of Laura seated at a table alone.
Galvin at the entrance to the restaurant looking at her. walks over to her slowly.
Laura, looks up, sees him, smiles. Her smile fades, she s that he knows.

Laura getting up from the table. We SEE her back, and Gal approaching. We SEE her shoulders droop, beaten. He draws closer. Galvin comes up to her, his face a mask of pain a confusion. She sighs, starts to speak. Stops. Beat. They  look at each other -- he starts to speak, cannot. He knoc her to the floor, she upsets the table. A large man at th next table starts to restrain Galvin.
(as if in shock) It's all right... it's all right...  it's all right... it's all right...
Galvin and Mickey seated next to him, flying home in sile Mickey smoking a cigarette. Galvin stone-faced, beat.

I talked to Johnnie White at the Bar  Association. (beat) The broad used to work for one of  Concannon's partners in New York  awhile ago. (beat; lamely) She wanted to move to Boston. (beat) How badly did she hurt us, Joe?
I don't know.
A beat.
We got a mistrial, you know. Joe --  did you hear what I said...?
I don't want a mistrial.
The doorway to his study. A basketball game dimly SEEN in the half-light. Mickey, o.s.:
He's not here. (pause) Yeah. I don't know when. (pause) All right.
Sound of him hanging up a telephone. He enters the frame  carrying a bottle of booze, goes through door into study.

head_text.subj: CAMERA FOLLOWS HIM INTO THE ROOM. THE TV

text: The Knicks are pressing hard... (etc.)

He sits on a sofa opposite the television. Watches the ga a beat. Opens the fresh bottle of whiskey and pours a lar shot into the almost-empty glass in front of him. Looks t his left. Reaches behind him to some glasses on a shelf,  takes one down, pours drink into the new glass, leans to left, CAMERA MOVES WITH him, and we SEE Galvin sitting in deep leather armchair, staring. Mickey offers him the dri Galvin becomes aware of him, shakes his head "no." Beat. Mickey moves back into his seat, they both stare at the  television.
Half full of spectators.
Galvin gets up from Plaintiff's table, takes up a large b as Dr. Towler takes the stands. He reads:

Dr. Towler; page 406,  'Contraindications to general  anesthetic. Ideally a patient should  refrain from taking nourishment up  to nine hours prior to induction of  general anesthetic.' Does that sound  familiar?
Yes. I wrote it.
Galvin shows the book.
'Practice and Methodology in  Anaesthesia.' General textbook on  the subject. Is that correct?
I. Yes. It is.
And you wrote that...
Yes.

(reading) ...Page 414, 'If a patient has taken  nourishment within one hour prior to  inducement, general anesthetic should  be avoided at all costs because of  the grave risk the patient will  aspirate food particles into his  mask.' Is that what happened to  Deborah Ann Kaye? She aspirated into  her mask?
She threw up in her mask, yes. But  she hadn't eaten one hour prior to  admission.
If she had eaten, say one hour prior  to admission, the inducement of a  general anesthetic... the type you  gave her... would have been  negligent...?
Negligent. Yes... it would have been  criminal. But that was not the case.
Thank you.
Galvin signals he is done. The Judge signals Dr. Towler t leave the stand, which he does.
Mr. Concannon...?
Nothing further, your Honor.
Mr. Galvin, rebuttal?
(to Bailiff) Katherine Price.
The Bailiff calls out her name.
Katherine Price...

Kathy at the back of the court, coming down the aisle. As she passes the Defendant's table, Towler grabs Marx and s whispering frantically. Concannon looks on, ignorant of w is happening. We hear Dr. Towler's "Oh, my God..."
Galvin surveys the courtroom, Kathy crosses in front of h takes the stand, we hear the Bailiff administering the fo as we WATCH Galvin turn and look at the Jurors.
State your name please.
Katherine Lynn Price.
D'you swear that the evidence you  are about to give will be the truth,  the...
The Bailiff swearing in Kathy.
...whole truth and nothing but the  truth, so help you God?
I do.
Be seated.
Kathy sits, the Bailiff retires, Galvin walks over to her
Kathy Price...
Yes...
You were the Admitting Nurse at St.  Catherine Laboure Hospital on May  twelfth, nineteen seventy-six, the  night Deborah Ann Kaye was admitted...
Yes.
Galvin holds up a form.
You signed this form?
She looks closely at it. Is satisfied.
Yes.
These are your initials, 'K.C.'?
Kathy Costello. That's my maiden  name.
A beat.
D'you ask the patient when did she  last eat?
Yes.
What did she say?
She said she had a full meal one  hour before coming to the hospital.
One hour.
Yes.
And did you write the numeral 'one'  down on the record, standing for one  hour?
I did.
A single hour.
Yes.
Galvin walks away from the witness box. He looks at the j He turns to look at the spectators. His thoughts are a mi miles away. Unconsciously he straightens his tie.
Galvin in front of the dead-still courtroom. He breaks hi reverie.
(to Concannon) Your witness.
Concannon is on his feet as Galvin walks back to his tabl Concannon walks over to Kathy and begins forcefully:
You are aware of the penalties for  perjury...?
It's a crime.
Yes. (beat) It is a crime. A serious crime.
I wouldn't do it.
You would not...?
No.
In fact, you've just taken an oath  that you would not commit perjury.  You've just sworn to that. Isn't  that right?
Yes.
Just now...
Yes.
...sworn before God you would tell  the truth?
(beat) Yes.

Now. I'd like to ask you something:  four years ago, when you were working  as a nurse, are you aware that Drs.  Towler and Marx based their treatment  of Deborah Ann Kaye on this chart  that you signed...?

And wasn't that an oath...? These  are your initials here: K.C. When  you signed this chart you took an  oath. No less important than that  which you took today. (beat) Isn't that right? (beat) Isn't that right...?
I... yes.
Then, please, which is correct? You've  sworn today the patient ate one hour  ago. Four years ago you swore she  ate nine hours ago? Which is the  lie. When were you lying?
You know these doctors could have  settled out of court. They wanted a  trial. They wanted to clear their  names.
Objection!
And you would come here, and on a  slip of memory four years ago, you'd  ruin their lives.
They lied.
'They lied.' Indeed! When did they  lie? And do you know what a lie is?
I do. Yes.
(holding chart) You swore on this form that the  patient ate nine hours ago.
That's not my handwriting.
You've just said you signed it.
Yes, I, yes, I signed it, yes. But  I, I didn't write that figure.
You didn't write that figure. And  how is it that you remember that so  clearly after four years?
(taking a paper out  of her purse) Because I kept a copy. I have it  right here.
She looks toward Galvin.
Galvin nods, meaning, "You did it perfectly."
Concannon, the Judge, Kathy.
Objection! This is ri... expect us  to accept a photocopy, we have the  original right...
I'll rule on that presently. (beat) Proceed.
Concannon is taken up short. Amazed at the Judge's reacti he pauses an instant.
Please proceed.

Concannon motions to Billy, the young lawyer, who nods in response and starts whispering instructions to his collea at the Defense table, who start leafing through their  lawbooks. Concannon takes up the fight again.
...what in the world would induce  you to make a photocopy of some  obscure record and hold it four years?  This is a... why? Why would you do  that?
I thought I would need it.
And why, please tell us, would you  think that?

After, after the operation, when  that poor girl, she went in a coma.  Dr. Towler called me in. He told me  he had five difficult deliveries in  a row and he was tired, and he never  looked at the admittance form. (beat) And he told me to change the form.  He told me to change the one to a  nine. (beat) Or else, or else, he said... (beat; starts to cry) He said he'd fire me. He said I'd  never work again... Who were these  men...? Who were these men...? I  wanted to be a nurse...
She is weeping copiously. A beat. She starts to get herse under control.
No further questions.
You may step down.
Beat. Kathy starts to get down. She looks to Galvin for  assurance. Galvin nods at her.
Mr. Galvin...?
Kathy getting down from the stand. The Judge addressing  Galvin.
Nothing further, your Honor...
Mr. Concannon...?

Concannon is signalled by Billy, the young lawyer at the  Defense table, who is gathering notes from his colleagues who have been researching during Kathy's speech. Concannon walks over to the table and is quickly "talked  through" the notes by Billy.
Mr. Concannon.
Concannon cuts Billy short, meaning, "Yes, I understand, far ahead of you," he takes the notes and returns to the  bench.

Thank you, your Honor. We object to  the copy of the admissions form as  incompetent and essentially hearsay  evidence and cite McGee versus State  of Indiana, U.S. 131 point 2 and 216  through 25 of the Uniform Code: 'The  admission of a duplicate document in  preference to an existing original  must presuppose the possibility of  alteration and so must be disallowed.'  And, your Honor, having given the  Plaintiff the leeway we would like  your ruling on this issue now: we  object to the admission of the Xerox  form.
...one moment, Mr. Concannon...
The Judge nods, meaning, "I am considering..."
The Judge. He is making some notations on a page in front him. He nods to himself, he has reached a decision. He lo up.

The document is disallowed, the jury  will be advised not to consider the  testimony of Kathy Costello regarding  the Xerox form. (explains to them) It's unsubstantiated and we can't  accept a copy in preference to the  original...

Thank you, your Honor. Further: Ms.  Costello is a rebuttal witness. As a  'Surprise Witness' she may only serve  to rebut direct testimony. As her  only evidentiary rebuttal was the  admitting form, which has been  disallowed I request that her entire  testimony be disallowed and the jury  advised that they must totally  disregard her appearance here.
I'm going to uphold that.
Galvin getting to his feet.
I object, your Honor...
Overruled...
Exception!
Noted. Thank you. (to Jury) Miss Costello was a rebuttal witness.  Her sole rebuttal was the document,  which has been disallowed...
Galvin, silent, fuming, sitting at the table.
Her entire testimony must be stricken  from the record. You shouldn't have  heard it, but you did. Now, that was  my mistake... and you must strike it  from your minds, give it no weight.
Galvin takes a sheet of legal paper and starts writing on it.
Legally it's over. Concannon was  brilliant.
Tell me about Kaitlin Costello.
There's nothing to tell. It's been  stricken from the record.
I know. Did you believe her?
All looking slightly to their right.
Mr. Galvin...?
In front of the full jury box. Beat.

You know, so much of the time we're  lost. We say, 'Please, God, tell us  what is right. Tell us what's true.  There is no justice. The rich win,  the poor are powerless...' We become  tired of hearing people lie. After a  time we become dead. A little dead.  We start thinking of ourselves as  victims. (pause) And we become victims. (pause) And we become weak... and doubt  ourselves, and doubt our  institutions... and doubt our  beliefs... we say for example, 'The  law is a sham... there is no law...  I was a fool for having believed  there was.' (beat) But today you are the law. You are  the law... And not some book and not  the lawyers, or the marble statues  and the trappings of the court...  all that they are is symbols. (beat) Of our desire to be just... (beat) All that they are, in effect, is a  prayer... (beat) ...a fervent, and a frightened prayer.

In my religion we say, 'Act as if  you had faith, and faith will be  given to you.' (beat) If... If we would have faith in  justice, we must only believe in  ourselves. (beat) And act with justice. (beat) And I believe that there is justice  in our hearts. (beat) Thank you.
He stands still a moment, then surveys the still courtroo
Laura in the corridor, watching him.
The Jurors filing in from the Jury Room.
Concannon, Young Lawyer, Dr. Towler, Dr. Marx at Defense  table. Young Lawyer scribbles a note, passes it to Concannon, wh ignores it.
Plaintiff's table. Galvin looking at the Jury, Mickey at other end of the table.
Have you reached a verdict?
We have, your Honor.
The Jury Box. The Jurors seated, the FOREMAN standing.
Your Honor, we have agreed to hold  for the Plaintiff... but on the size  of the award, are we bound...
You are not bound by anything, other  than your good judgment, based on  the evidence.
Galvin, totally defeated. Nods his head sadly, as if  commiserating philosophically, with himself. Mickey looks him in grief, with sympathy.
Are we permitted to award an amount  greater than the amount the Plaintiff  asked for?
Galvin slowly raises his head, turns and looks at the Jur Mickey begins to smile.
Yes. You are.
The courtroom, commotion.
Please retire and...

Galvin and Mickey standing near a back staircase, cleanin equipment is lying all around. A large, battered garbage  can. Mickey is lighting Galvin's cigarette. Galvin's hand shakes badly. Something draws his attention at the end of the corridor. He turns his head. ANGLE - P.O.V. Laura, standing at the end of the corridor. Tentative, lo pleading silently, she holds a sheet of yellow legal pape in her hand. ANGLE - INSERT - LAURA'S P.O.V.
'Laura. I'm going to try. When this is over can we go awa 'Joe' 'Thank you' ANGLE - GALVIN'S P.O.V. Laura holding the paper.
Galvin and Mickey looking at her. Galvin's face impassive Beat. He turns his back on her. Mickey does likewise. Beat.
